title: Quiz 6: Head & Neck II (Nerves & Special Senses)
description: Advanced assessment covering the 12 cranial nerves, anatomy of the eye and orbit, ear mechanics, pharynx, larynx, and deep neck structures.

questions.question: Match the extraocular muscle with its specific cranial nerve supply:
questions.explanation: Formula: LR6, SO4, All others 3. (Lateral Rectus = CN6; Superior Oblique = CN4; Rest = CN3). Orbicularis Oculi closes the eye and is supplied by the Facial nerve.
questions.hint: Remember the chemical formula 'LR6SO4'.

questions.question: A patient presents with a 'blown' (dilated) pupil and the eye is positioned 'down and out'. Which nerve is damaged?
questions.explanation: CN III (Oculomotor) supplies the constrictor pupillae (parasympathetic) and most eye movers. Damage leads to unopposed dilator action (blown pupil) and unopposed pull of LR and SO (down and out).
questions.hint: This nerve controls most eye movements and pupil constriction.

questions.question: Which of the following are components of the Middle Ear? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Middle Ear contains the ossicles and communicates with the nasopharynx via the Eustachian tube. The Cochlea and Semicircular canals are part of the Inner Ear.
questions.hint: Structures involved in conducting sound, not transducing it.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ nerve provides general sensation to the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, while the ___BLANK___ nerve provides taste to the same area.
questions.explanation: General sensation (pain/touch) = Lingual nerve (from V3). Taste = Chorda Tympani (from VII).
questions.hint: One is a branch of the Trigeminal; the other hitchhikes from the Facial.

questions.question: The optic chiasma is where fibers from the TEMPORAL halves of the retina cross over.
questions.explanation: FALSE. Fibers from the NASAL halves of the retina cross at the chiasma. Temporal fibers stay on the same side.
questions.hint: Nasal fibers see the temporal field.

questions.question: Which muscle of the larynx is the ONLY abductor of the vocal cords?
questions.explanation: The Posterior Cricoarytenoid is the sole abductor (opens the airway). The Lateral Cricoarytenoid adducts. Cricothyroid tenses (pitch).
questions.hint: It pulls the muscular process posteriorly to swing the vocal cords open.

questions.question: Match the Parasympathetic Ganglion with its associated Cranial Nerve:
questions.explanation: CN III -> Ciliary (Eye). CN VII -> Pterygopalatine (Lacrimal) & Submandibular (Salivary). CN IX -> Otic (Parotid).
questions.hint: COPS: Ciliary, Otic, Pterygopalatine, Submandibular.

questions.question: Trace the path of light through the eye:
questions.explanation: Light passes through Cornea -> Aqueous -> Pupil/Lens -> Vitreous -> Retina.
questions.hint: Front to back.

questions.question: Which nerve innervates the Cricothyroid muscle?
questions.explanation: The External Laryngeal nerve (branch of Superior Laryngeal) supplies the Cricothyroid. ALL other intrinsic muscles are supplied by the Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve.
questions.hint: It is an 'external' muscle on the laryngeal surface.

questions.question: Review the clinical scenario. A patient has loss of the Corneal Reflex. Which nerve limbs could be damaged?

richContent.content: Reflex Arc: The corneal reflex involves touching the cornea (sensation) and the resulting blink (motor response).

options.text: Afferent: CN II; Efferent: CN III
Afferent: CN V1; Efferent: CN VII
Afferent: CN VII; Efferent: CN V1
Afferent: CN IX; Efferent: CN X

questions.explanation: Sensation from the cornea is carried by the Ophthalmic nerve (V1). The motor response (closing the eye) is by the Facial nerve (VII).
questions.hint: Feeling the touch vs Closing the eyelid.

questions.question: Which specific dural venous sinus lies on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone and contains the Internal Carotid Artery?
questions.explanation: The Cavernous Sinus contains the Internal Carotid Artery and CN VI (Abducent) inside it, with CN III, IV, V1, V2 in the lateral wall.
questions.hint: It is named for its cavern-like trabeculated structure.

questions.question: Which of the following nerves carry Parasympathetic fibers? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The cranial outflow of the parasympathetic system is carried by CN III, VII, IX, and X. (3, 7, 9, 10). CN V carries fibers as 'passengers' but does not originate them.

questions.question: Where does the nasolacrimal duct drain?
questions.explanation: The nasolacrimal duct (tears) drains into the Inferior Meatus. Frontal/Maxillary/Ant Ethmoidal drain to Middle Meatus. Post Ethmoidal to Superior. Sphenoid to Recess.
questions.hint: Tears flow down to the lowest space.

questions.question: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) supplies all intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue EXCEPT the Palatoglossus.
questions.explanation: TRUE. Palatoglossus is a muscle of the palate (supplied by Pharyngeal plexus - CN X). All other 'glossus' muscles are CN XII.
questions.hint: Palatoglossus is the exception.

questions.question: Arrange the ossicles of the ear from Lateral (Tympanic membrane) to Medial (Oval window):
questions.explanation: M-I-S: Malleus (attached to drum), Incus, Stapes (attached to oval window).
questions.hint: Hammer, Anvil, Stirrup.

questions.question: Which artery is the primary blood supply to the visual cortex of the brain?
questions.explanation: The Posterior Cerebral Artery (terminal branch of Basilar) supplies the occipital lobe (visual cortex).
questions.hint: The visual cortex is at the back (posterior) of the brain.

questions.question: Match the pharyngeal arch derivatives (nerve supply) to the region:
questions.explanation: Arch 1 = V; Arch 2 = VII; Arch 3 = IX; Arch 4/6 = X. (Mnemonic: 5, 7, 9, 10).
questions.hint: The nerve numbers increase as you go down the arches.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ sinus lies directly below the Pituitary Fossa (Sella Turcica).
questions.explanation: The Sphenoidal air sinus is located in the body of the sphenoid, directly beneath the pituitary gland (allowing trans-sphenoidal surgery).
questions.hint: The sinus in the middle of the skull base.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of a Third Nerve (Oculomotor) Palsy? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Inability to close the eye tightly

questions.explanation: CN III Palsy: Ptosis (levator paralysis), Mydriasis (parasympathetic loss), 'Down and Out' position. Inability to close the eye is CN VII palsy.
questions.hint: The eye is closed, pupil is big, eyeball looks down/out.

questions.question: The vocal cords are lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The vocal cords are lined by STRATIFIED SQUAMOUS epithelium (to withstand friction). The rest of the larynx is respiratory epithelium.
questions.hint: They vibrate and rub together; they need tough skin.

questions.question: Which nerve is responsible for the 'Gag Reflex' (Afferent limb)?
questions.explanation: Afferent (Sensation): Glossopharyngeal (IX). Efferent (Motor): Vagus (X).
questions.hint: The nerve that senses the back of the tongue/pharynx.

questions.question: What is the specialized area of the retina responsible for high-acuity central vision?
questions.explanation: The Macula Lutea (with the Fovea Centralis) is the area of highest visual acuity, containing mostly cones.
questions.hint: It is yellowish in appearance.

questions.question: The Tensor Palati muscle wraps around which bony hook to enter the soft palate?

options.text: Hamulus of the medial pterygoid plate

questions.explanation: Tensor Palati uses the Pterygoid Hamulus as a pulley to redirect its force horizontally to tense the palate.
questions.hint: A hook-like process on the pterygoid plate.

questions.question: Which part of the internal ear is responsible for static equilibrium (sense of position/gravity)?
questions.explanation: Utricle/Saccule (Vestibule) = Static position/Gravity. Semicircular ducts = Angular acceleration/Rotation. Cochlea = Hearing.
questions.hint: The parts in the vestibule.

questions.question: The parotid gland is supplied by parasympathetic fibers from the Otic Ganglion.
questions.explanation: TRUE. The Glossopharyngeal nerve sends fibers to the Otic ganglion, which then travel via the Auriculotemporal nerve to the Parotid.
questions.hint: Glossopharyngeal -> Otic -> Parotid.
